reviews.text: You could argue that Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy is one of the Mt. Rushmore comedies, a pitch-perfect character study combined with some incredible set pieces, unforgettable jokes and scathing commentary.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: “Anchorman” has a number of great scenes and I found myself laughing out loud numerous times. Unfortunately I found myself rolling my eyes just as much.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: The men are crude, the weatherman (Steve Carell) has the intellectual depth of a dust bunny, and the news teams swagger around town like overdressed street gangs who rumble when they collide.
reviews.author: Sean Axmaker

reviews.text: One of the greatest comedies of all time. Pure genius. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: The blooper reel at the end credits proves that this group must have had a grand time making the film - perhaps more than viewers will have watching the finished product.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: Absolutely riotous!! Ron Burgundy, the man with a nose for news and one fine looking head of helmet hair. Anchorman - it brings you comedy so you don't have to go find it.
reviews.author: Debbie Lynn Elias

reviews.text: Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy is one of the best comedies of this century.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: He's sure to offend viewers who don't see the humor in such stuff. [But Ron Burgundy] highlights the truth about television news. It's entertainment disguised as information.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Overstreet

reviews.text: Will Ferrell is superb as Ron Burgundy, an egocentric legend of TV's nightly news who could only have existed in the 1970s.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: The uneven comedy is sometimes amusing but too often it's a bad joke prolonged.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Incredibly silly yet often hilarious...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: [A] very funny, silly, and well acted comedy that must be watched for the great laugh out loud performances, and gut busting gags.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: Silly comedy that's definitely not for kids
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: It's nearly perfect.
reviews.author: Rob Humanick

reviews.text: By no means ... a great movie. But I not only understand why some people love it, I think I'm even beginning to love it a little myself.
reviews.author: Philip Martin

reviews.text: Laughs galore follow the well-paced humor as cameo performances by Jack Black, Tim Robbins, and Luke Wilson spice up the buffoonery ingeniously smacked at by the rest of movie's talented ensemble.
reviews.author: Cole Smithey

reviews.text: Relentlessly silly but not quite funny parody of 70s network news never quite lives up to its promise.
reviews.author: Joe Lozito

reviews.text: Some of the material works, some doesn't.
reviews.author: Urban Cinefile Critics

reviews.text: This goofy, energetic comedy flattens out at times but milks its 1970s setting and characters for numerous huge laughs.
reviews.author: Mark Halverson

reviews.text: ...like a 'Saturday Night Live' skit that got out of hand, a good idea that kept going and going but never quite jelled into a story.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: A crude, funny satire that tackles local television anchors and their newscasts. Those are easy targets to skewer, but the movie mines more truth from its subject than some in the biz will want to admit.
reviews.author: Christopher Smith

reviews.text: Some of "Anchorman" is the kind of giddy, nonsensical stuff that can only emerge from a genuinely deranged comic brain.
reviews.author: Rob Gonsalves

reviews.text: Ostensibly modeled on the egomaniacal Ted Baxter of the old Mary Tyler Moore TV series, this adventure's protagonist is less comical, less endearing, and generally grates on the nerves.
reviews.author: Kam Williams

reviews.text: Takes a joke and runs with it -- sometimes too far, but usually long enough to wear you down and force you to submit to its craziness.
reviews.author: Anna Smith

reviews.text: Word is Ferrell got the idea for the film one night while watching a documentary on the male dominated world of 70s television news. His fans should thank their lucky stars the comedian happened to catch it.
reviews.author: Rick Kisonak

reviews.text: There hasn't been a movie this silly or funny since Austin Powers.
reviews.author: Scott Nash

reviews.text: ...somehow Will Farrell manages to hold the whole mess together.
reviews.author: Uri Lessing

reviews.text: Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy shows that the past has bright future in Hollywood comedies.
reviews.author: Dragan Antulov

reviews.text: Ferrell's manic energy takes it beyond parody and into a brilliant dance of buffoonery.
reviews.author: Jason Zingale

reviews.text: So funny that you won't care that it has no real plot but boasts more bad wigs than The Lord of the Rings...
reviews.author: Brian Juergens

reviews.text: Fans of the Todd Phillips school of comedy are going to be divided on this one -- there's real potential here and a great premise but had it been a little cleverer it could've been so much more.
reviews.author: Garth Franklin

reviews.text: Overall, I put Anchorman on about the same level as Dodgeball. Both movies are pretty stupid and don't generate as many laughs as you wish they would.
reviews.author: Ethan Alter

reviews.text: Nothing in Anchorman will be mistaken for the work of Preston Sturges, but the occasional chuckle and even a loud guffaw is unavoidable.
reviews.author: Dan Lybarger

reviews.text: Misses a golden opportunity by crossing the line that separates parody from stupidity.
reviews.author: Tony Medley

reviews.text: A straight shot of that good stuff.
reviews.author: Alan Dale

reviews.text: If we want to judge Anchorman by its own standards, we can observe that nothing in the movie lives up to, say, Toonces the driving cat.
reviews.author: Thomas Peyser

reviews.text: Avoid Anchorman like the plague, you'll thank me later.
reviews.author: Joe Utichi

reviews.text: Ferrell wrenches every drop of ingenuity from a lackluster screenplay and amplifies it through his face, his voice, his gut - even his underwear.
reviews.author: Mark Collette

reviews.text: Certainly the silliest comedy of the year, but mainly in a good way.
Doesn't quite live up to the promise of its admittedly funny trailer, though it does have several good laugh-out-loud gags.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: This is ideal Friday night fodder if you're in the right mood.
reviews.author: Nev Pierce

reviews.text: Generally, the film makes good on its humorous potential.
reviews.author: Michael Drakulich

reviews.text: The period vibe is basically the whole point to this charming and often very funny film.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: The good news is - the film is fresh, imaginative and full of laughs.
reviews.author: Tony Toscano

reviews.text: balances its social satire with some outlandish visual gags and moments of surreal hilarity
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: Ferrell is at the top of his game, giving us a character who is utterly shallow, silly, and vainglorious, yet completely likable.
reviews.author: Brian Mckay

reviews.text: If you don't like Will Ferrell, I don't understand you. I mean, this movie might just change your mind.
reviews.author: Michael W. Phillips, Jr.

reviews.text: Rent it if you must, but don't say I didn't warn you.
reviews.author: Karina Montgomery

reviews.text: Surprise surprise, the movie outplays its trailer. Picks up big well-deserved laughs in between ever decreasing non-funny moments.
reviews.author: Ross Anthony

reviews.text: All those comedy smarts boils down to one indisputable fact: Anchorman is the single funniest thing Will Ferrell has done yet.
reviews.author: David Cornelius

reviews.text: Anchorman has a good-natured attitude to go along with its hit-or-miss jokes, and Ferrell's willingness to humiliate himself for a laugh should count for something.
reviews.author: Daniel Eagan

reviews.text: Resembling Bill Murray's early career, Ron Burgundy is a Peter Venkman/Carl Spackler type performance which will be remember fondly during Will Ferrell's 2020 Oscar run.
reviews.author: Stephen Himes

reviews.text: Half of Anchorman had me laughing on cue; the other half made me want to switch channels.
reviews.author: Thomas Delapa

reviews.text: Generally funny, but for the first half hour it's hilarious.
reviews.author: Mark Palermo

reviews.text: But it isn't, and instead all we get is a tiredly over-the-top, overly improvised farce that relies more on the popularity of its star than it does on little things like character, story or continuity.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: To praise Anchorman for perceptive social commentary would be giving the movie more credit than it deserves, but it isn't just pratfalls and sexual humour.
reviews.author: Brian Webster

reviews.text: A strange, funny movie about a strange, funny guy.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: O diretor já revelou que um segundo filme, produzido apenas com as cenas deletadas deste, será incluído no DVD. Será que a pré-venda já começou?
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: The period detail is hilarious, abetted fantastically by Alex Wurman's score. But there's so much talent on hand that you couldn't blame anyone for wanting more.
reviews.author: Jake Euker

reviews.text: Watching Ferrell and crew put the uproar in uproarious makes you forget, if only for a while, today's worst news.
reviews.author: Randy Shulman

reviews.text: ...about as entertaining as a TV test pattern.
reviews.author: Lori Hoffman

reviews.text: Consistently funny, more often than not of the cheap variety.
reviews.author: Jim Chastain

reviews.text: Slaps a goofy smile on your face.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: The weirder Anchorman gets, the stronger its comedy.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Westhoff

reviews.text: At best fitfully amusing for all but hardcore Ferrell fans.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: I could have used more smarm and crisply delineated battle-of-sexes confrontation, but Ferrell's overwrought mania and wholesale comedic devotion again sell the laffs.
reviews.author: Brent Simon

reviews.text: Although Anchorman is packed with genuine laughs and a plethora of pleasant-surprise cameos, the film's cardboard characters and lifeless storyline is a step backward for Ferrell in his otherwise escalating big-screen career.
reviews.author: Tyler Hanley

reviews.text: Will said on a recent talk show that he got the idea from watching a documentary on news and was captivated by the 70's anchors.
reviews.author: Vince Koehler

reviews.text: Ron Burgundy is a boob on the boob tune whose antics get stale before the movie ends.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: Perfectly captures the hilarious desperation of the local news personality.
reviews.author: Jimmy O

reviews.text: ...consistently ridiculous and hysterical, despite its messy mid-movie abandonment of the subject it sets out to parody.
reviews.author: Aaron Hillis

reviews.text: There are a ton of jokes launched, and most of them work.
reviews.author: Danny Minton

reviews.text: It sinks like an anchor, man.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: What we get is more of the same from Ferrell -- funny faces, goofy accents, pratfalls aplenty -- and that ain't bad. It just could have been a lot better.
reviews.author: Kimberley Jones

reviews.text: In the end, it really hinges on Ferrell's burgeoning star power and the contributions of his scene-stealing supporting cast.
reviews.author: Wade Major

reviews.text: ...we all get one of the funniest movies of the year...
reviews.author: Eric Campos

reviews.text: Not since last year's Old School have I actually laughed afterward at a film's gags, remembering each one as if seeing it for the first time.
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: This one's crazy, silly, funny and whole lotta loony, but as a cohesive movie movie...it's also kind of a mess.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: A hoot that comes to an unfortunate halt every time the newsteams go over the top.
reviews.author: Harvey S. Karten

reviews.text: Even if many of the film's individual characters aren't worth remembering an hour after you see the movie, Anchorman is almost always hilarious.
reviews.author: Mark Bazer

reviews.text: It has a pleasing, noodly elasticity about it -- the picture knows what its limits are and proceeds to boogie unself-consciously far outside them.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: Screenwriters Will Ferrell and Adam McKay have brought us a twisted tribute to sexual harassment...
reviews.author: Eric Lurio

reviews.text: All hail Will Ferrell, King of the man-children!
reviews.author: Martin Scribbs

reviews.text: This wildly uneven comedy goes from the heights of zaniness to the depths of bad-sketch humor, sometimes in the same scene.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: You go ... hoping for good, dumb fun. Well, one out of three ain't bad. But that doesn't exactly make Anchorman good, either.
reviews.author: Carol Cling

reviews.text: It's not a comedy.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: Ron Burgundy takes his place among the multitude of amusing characters portrayed by one of today's most talented comics.
reviews.author: Betty Jo Tucker

reviews.text: A surreally dopey comedy that is refreshingly ribald without resorting to gross-out humor, and its '70s-savvy soundtrack may be worth the price of admission.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: At its best it plays like modern-day Marx Brothers in which every single thing that happens makes no sense and serves no purpose and nothing happens for any reason at all.
reviews.author: Robert Wilonsky

reviews.text: Wonderfully silly all the time.
reviews.author: Desson Thomson

reviews.text: You will laugh. Then you will laugh some more. Then you will laugh still again.
reviews.author: Stephen Hunter

reviews.text: May cause hysterical fits of laughter -- stay tuned for further details.
reviews.author: Angel Cohn

reviews.text: Like most of these sofa-spud comedies, Anchorman bears its attention-deficit disorder proudly, as it shifts tone and abruptly sidetracks.
reviews.author: Geoff Pevere

reviews.text: Occasionally, it entertains us for three minutes or so, but it lurches from one skitlike scene to another, charting out like this: funny, not funny, not funny, funny, not, not, not, funny, not, funny, not, not.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: While the film is sporadically funny, it was done much better on the small screen, decades ago.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: A comic idea that never finds the comic wellspring or anything resembling a sure source for laughs.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: The laughs arrive on stale crackers of the easy, breezy and familiar.
reviews.author: David Elliott

reviews.text: There isn't a second that goes by without Ferrell filling it with some form of comic shtick - a well-turned punch line, a goofy facial expression, a pratfall or some other kind of physical comedy business.
reviews.author: Joe Baltake

reviews.text: A mighty silly send-up of a mighty silly era.
reviews.author: Jack Garner

reviews.text: The SNL veteran's willingness to do anything for a laugh, no matter how humiliating or juvenile, keeps the laughs flowing pretty steadily in this fast paced send up of seventies era news anchors in all their blown dry, polyester glory.
reviews.author: Timothy Knight

reviews.text: Add it all up, and you get something that often meets the standard of being funny. Whether it meets the standard of being a movie is another question.
reviews.author: Gary Thompson

reviews.text: Most of it isn't even as funny as those supposedly humorous features that local news broadcasts sometimes end with.
reviews.author: Jay Boyar

reviews.text: Nothing more than an extended skit, and a lame one at that.
reviews.author: Karen Karbo

reviews.text: The celluloid equivalent of a throwaway summer pop anthem, the sort of catchy-yet-agitating tune that has you humming in spite of yourself.
reviews.author: Lisa Rose

reviews.text: Ferrell is funny spouting his weird stream-of-consciousness rants, but too often the plot leaves him hanging and he resorts to just Yelling Really Loud.
reviews.author: Megan Lehmann

reviews.text: As much credit as Ferrell deserves for keeping this nonsense from slipping off the screen, Applegate deserves as well.
reviews.author: Jack Mathews

reviews.text: The desperate and frantic slapstick of Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy is closer to hysteria than hysterical.
reviews.author: Duane Dudek

reviews.text: What takes the whole thing pleasurably over the top, turning a goof into a total gas, is the film's pitch-perfect absurdist comedy and warmth.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: You're just left wishing that Tina Fey had lent a helping hand -- or that they'd wheeled in some old hands from the real '70s newsroom gender comedy, The Mary Tyler Moore Show.
reviews.author: Bob Strauss

reviews.text: Ferrell makes this a movie worth your money, and you'll leave the theater laughing.
reviews.author: Sam Sessa

reviews.text: It's one of those movies where every good joke is in the trailer, which was a hilarious two-minute spot that promised so much more than this sloppy, lazy effort manages to deliver.
reviews.author: Derek Tse

reviews.text: With the ability to throw all caution -- and sometimes all clothes -- to the wind, Ferrell has that unique ability to be both funny and vulnerable at the same time, a quality that makes him hard not to like.
reviews.author: Drew McAnulty

reviews.text: Anchorman would qualify as great popcorn entertainment, except that the popcorn will become a choking hazard because you'll be guffawing so much.
reviews.author: Louis B. Hobson

reviews.text: Overly broad humor with little on its mind.
reviews.author: Bruce Westbrook

reviews.text: Ferrell has an absolutely magical way of making complete morons lovable.
reviews.author: Tom Long

reviews.text: There are more misfires and dead spots than we'd prefer, but they're outweighed by many more moments that are riotously laugh-out-loud funny.
reviews.author: Jeff Vice

reviews.text: No need to make room for Anchorman in any cultural time capsule, but there are enough laughs to keep the movie from being canceled.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Always affectionate toward its people, especially when they are at their most ridiculous, Anchorman meticulously builds America's dimmest news team. And we root for them.
reviews.author: Michael Booth

reviews.text: It's 'Jane, you ignorant slut' all over again, but with less bite, a backstory, a romance and a host of celebrity cameos that promise more than they deliver.
reviews.author: Mary F. Pols

reviews.text: A lot of the time it's very funny.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: Sloppy, crude, pursuing the most far-flung tangents in hopes of a laugh, Anchorman still gave me more stupid giggles than I'd care to admit if I weren't paid to.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: Although it has even less depth than its proudly one-dimensional hero, 'Anchorman' is frequently hilarious and full of delightful cameos by some familiar faces.
reviews.author: James Sanford

reviews.text: You finally got me, Will Ferrell. I surrender.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: Half inspired and half a moronic exercise in brain stagnation.
reviews.author: Donald Munro

reviews.text: Nearly as offensive as it is funny.
reviews.author: Audrey Rock-Richardson

reviews.text: News Flash - it's not that funny!
reviews.author: Cherryl Dawson and Leigh Ann Palone

reviews.text: Anchorman works so well because Ferrell's persona fits flawlessly into this world of overgrown boys working men's jobs.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: No plot, no so-called redeeming social value and no desire to pluck the hearstrings, which is why it's superior to 'Elf.'
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: Ferrell at the top of his craft...
reviews.author: JoBlo

reviews.text: Knights of Columbus! Wouldn't it be great if TV-based comedians weren't afraid of making movies that were funnier than they are?
reviews.author: Stephen Cole

reviews.text: These are obviously just stitched-together bits that these improv masters worked through until they got funny. Their dedication pays off more often than not, especially when the cast strives for outrageousness.
reviews.author: E! Staff

reviews.text: Anchorman is an absurd, stupid comedy that's a lot of fun and well worth checking out at the theater with friends.
reviews.author: Scott Chitwood

reviews.text: We really can't call this a sophomore slump. Does sophomoric slump work?
reviews.author: Sean O'Connell

reviews.text: You'll be more likely to scratch your head in puzzlement than to pull your mouth into a smile
reviews.author: Marty Mapes

reviews.text: Although great in small doses, Anchorman struggles to sustain its concept through feature length.
reviews.author: Jon Niccum

reviews.text: I hoped for far more laughs, a sharper edge to the humor and a comedy that would attain the rank of other SNL alum works such as Caddyshack.
reviews.author: Judith Egerton

reviews.text: Anchorman may be uneven, but Will Ferrell's Ron Burgundy is a character worth revisiting
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: An enthusiastic, harmlessly silly celebration of the empancipation of the TV newsroom.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: This is a masterpiece of comedy, ready to be watched, re-watched, quoted and imitated for years to come.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: Ferrell totally gets the anchorman of the 70s vibe and pulls off even the lamest lines without breaking a sweat
reviews.author: Rebecca Murray

reviews.text: [N]inety endless minutes of some of the most stunningly incompetent filmmaking I've ever seen...
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: Will Ferrell headlines a great comedy cast in a story that is as ridiculous as it is hysterical.
reviews.author: Jeff Otto

reviews.text: It's hardly breaking news to tell you Will Ferrell's funny, but Anchorman's flights of lunacy need a little more story to keep us engaged.
reviews.author: James Rocchi

reviews.text: Gags aren't allowed to develop; the characters are shuffled from location to location and from conflict to conflict without building momentum.
reviews.author: Eugene Novikov

reviews.text: Captures the mood of a group of friends riffing, trying to make each other laugh with the most ridiculous nonsense they can think of
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: Isn't as strong as Dodgeball or Starsky and Hutch primarily because the satire inherent in these flicks isn't paid as much attention to this time around.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Chen

reviews.text: The humor of Anchorman is planted deep within a surreal 70s landscape where the jokes zing by so fast, you have zero time to ponder how out there they really are.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: While malapropisms and anachronisms do have their places in cinematic comedy, it's very tough to make them the foundation for a story.
reviews.author: Edward Havens

reviews.text: A 'Stupid Comedy' that gleefully celebrates the absurd and actually trusts its audience to be smart.
reviews.author: Collin Souter

reviews.text: The whole exercise has the smug feeling of a Kevin Smith film-- a cameo dumpster that doesn't even have the wit to kill Danny Trejo.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: This is a wobbly comedy rooted too deeply in three- or four-minute TV-style set pieces, which misfire more often than not.
reviews.author: Larry Ratliff

reviews.text: It is not as maniacally uninhibited as Old School or as dementedly lovable as Elf, but its cheerful dumbness is hard to resist.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: It's a flat, dull picture marked by sporadic flashes of ridiculous brilliance.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: Little more than an extended Saturday Night Live skit with better wigs, real locations and a script that sputters as soon as its one-joke premise is exhausted.
reviews.author: Terry Lawson

reviews.text: Hammers away at the same comedic notes like an 8-year-old pounding out 'Chopsticks' on a parlor piano.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: Keeps re-establishing Ron's egomania with diminishing returns of cleverness. The film goes nowhere.
reviews.author: Philip Wuntch

reviews.text: For every gag that works, there's one that doesn't, and the story is too thin to keep us engaged otherwise.
reviews.author: Bill Muller

reviews.text: Partway through the uneven string of skits that comprises Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy, the film loses its mind completely.
reviews.author: Cynthia Fuchs

reviews.text: There is enough goofy humor to satisfy the guy in me but "Anchorman" has too many problems to propel it to the heights of Ferrell's recent vehicles.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: That he can make his anchorman chauvinistic, deluded and ridiculous but still manage to give him some humanity is testimony to Ferrell's comic talents.
reviews.author: Claudia Puig

reviews.text: Even if it's not exactly dripping with substance, it's still one of the most distinct comedies to come out this year -- distinctly stupid at times, yes, but also with a fresh and funny voice of its own.
reviews.author: Phoebe Flowers

reviews.text: You're not laughing at anchormen. You're laughing at formula movie rituals blown sky-high.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: It's essentially a one-joke situation carried to a tedious length and Ferrell hardly runs away with his cliched part.
reviews.author: William Arnold

reviews.text: Burgundy is dim, vain and unrepentantly horny, but there is something so limited about him that he seems more pitiable than funny.
reviews.author: Bruce Newman

reviews.text: The barrage of very funny jokes makes up for any missteps, and by the end of the film you'll likely only remember the good parts.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: An engagingly knuckleheaded comic vehicle for former Saturday Night Live trouper Will Ferrell.
reviews.author: Steven Rea

reviews.text: essentially ninety minutes of name-calling and surprise cameos masquerading as comedy
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: I think Anchorman has the potential to achieve Austin Powers-like status as a highly quotable movie.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: Ron may be an idiot, but Anchorman is no dope.
reviews.author: John Anderson

reviews.text: It's a long string of heavy-footed sight and sound gags that must have seemed a stitch at the drawing board, but made me squirm in my seat.
reviews.author: Ella Taylor

reviews.text: Dumb, dumber, dumberest!
reviews.author: David Sterritt

reviews.text: It's a cute, silly, likable movie without much weight or intensity, but it's also pretty funny.
reviews.author: Michael Wilmington

reviews.text: It solidifies Ferrell's place alongside Jim Carrey, Jack Black and, when called on, Johnny Depp, as our best comic actors.
reviews.author: Eleanor Ringel Cater

reviews.text: it seems like Ferrell can take just about any idea, however threadbare, and make it funny.
reviews.author: Austin O'Connor

reviews.text: Even though it feels the need to lapse into juvenile clowning around every once in awhile, Anchorman is still gonna make you laugh--hard.
reviews.author: Kit Bowen

reviews.text: Instantly quotable and destined for classic comedic status.
reviews.author: Nick Rogers

reviews.text: ...Burgundy barely qualifies as a character. Better to think of him as a living one-liner, albeit a very funny one.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: so many ways to go with something witty, sharp, or just plain fun . . .the filmmakers instead went with pointless, dull, obvious, and sophomoric
reviews.author: Andrea Chase

reviews.text: It's the kind of movie that makes you laugh despite yourself, its inconsistent dummheit redeemed by a try-anything approach that somewhat transcends the usual aura of a TV sketch stretched to feature length.
reviews.author: Steve Schneider

reviews.text: Good dumb fun can be lowbrow without being lazy, but bite-sized episodes of creative lunacy are not enough to qualify Anchorman as the kind of dumb worth paying to see.
reviews.author: Rob Blackwelder

reviews.text: The results may not be coherent, or even consistent, but they are often hilarious.
reviews.author: David Thomas

reviews.text: "Anchorman" is so deft and suave at selling us on its preposterousness that we give in, and laugh at the sheer gall of it all.
reviews.author: Steven Snyder

reviews.text: the movie succeeds because there are so many goofy little moments that rise up out of nowhere and catch you off guard.
reviews.author: Sean McBride

reviews.text: Will Ferrell shows that even he is not immune to looking bad when faced with bad material, even if it's his own. Possibly one of the worst directed films of the year.
reviews.author: Boo Allen

reviews.text: For a comedy set during the formative era of happy-talk news, Anchorman doesn't do enough to tweak the on-camera phoniness of dum-dum local journalism.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: This is one of the funniest movies of the year...
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: Whether he's fighting Kodiak bears or throwing burritos at bikers, Ron Burgundy is the perfect outlet for Will's unique brand of sincere witticism.
reviews.author: Joshua Tyler

reviews.text: Anchorman is equally hilarious, appalling and intelligent, but couldn't the movie have a little more of the intelligent and hilarious?
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: Most of the comic sequences and satirical barbs in this comedy seem to have been recycled from the long ago past.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: A marginal entertainment with some greatly funny scenes definitely worth seeing, but is the rest of the movie worth wading through to get to them? Probably not.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: Will Ferrell's commitment to sophomoric comedy is encroaching on religious zeal: "Anchorman" is Ferrell at his best.
reviews.author: David Foucher

reviews.text: A coarse, one-joke affair; Ron Burgundy might not have actually been an SNL skit, but 'Anchorman' sure feels like a movie based on one.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: As parody, it's toothless and often smug, but as random Ferrellspeak generator, it has its delights.
reviews.author: Ed Park

reviews.text: Farrell carries the movie on his broad shoulders, nailing the character perfectly.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Ferrell has seized on a clever concept rife with possibilities -- namely, women breaking the glass ceiling in male-dominated TV news during the '70s -- and smartly surrounded himself with a topnotch cast.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Proving that even infantile humor can be funny, Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy does make you laugh even if you hate yourself for doing so.
reviews.author: Kirk Honeycutt

reviews.text: ... the laugh ratio is about 50 percent, but that's still pretty good.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: It's difficult to resist a hero who believes that the name San Diego, derived from German, means "whale's vagina."
reviews.author: Nick Schager

synopsis: Hotshot television anchorman Ron Burgundy welcomes upstart reporter Veronica Corningstone into the male-dominated world of 1970s broadcast news -- that is, until the talented female journalist begins to outshine Burgundy on air. Soon he grows jealous, begins a bitter feud with Veronica and eventually makes a vulgar slip on live TV that ruins his career. However, when an outrageous story breaks at the San Diego Zoo, Ron may get a chance to redeem himself.
